frameDefinitions: The words in this frame describe the 'fictive' motion of a stationary Road.
Words in this frame have to do with a Cognizer believing that some Phenomenon will take place in the future.
An Experiencer feels bad about a choice, an Action, or a failure to do something, which they now consider to have been a mistake or wrong.
The words in this frame describe an Experiencer's emotions with respect to some Content.

A Manner describes general or specific characteristics of an event in one of three ways:  First, it can refer to how a Comparison_event transpires, absent the influence of an entity (e.g. 'the way you talk').
An Agent has committed a Wrong in the past and is making Amends for it.
frameExamples: The long mountain road <t>meandered</t> through the woods.
Smithers did not <t>repent</t> of his crime.
My <t>enjoyment</t> of the movie was considerably impaired by the seven-foot guy sitting in front of me.
He completed the task in a fervent <t>manner</t>.
He <t>atoned</t> for his sin with good works.
listRoleDefinitions: Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of the <fen>Road</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. In particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
The trajectory that would be followed by one moving on the <fen>Road</fen>.
Any expression which tells where the fictive mover travelling along a <fen>Road</fen> would end up.

A physical path that a virtual moving entity can be imagined to travel along.
<fex name='Road'>The bike trail</fex> <t>zigzagged</t> through the woods.
This frame element is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path.
The configuration formed by the entire <fen>Path</fen> along the <fen>Road</fen>.
The direction in which a 'fictive' mover would travel along a <fen>Road</fen>.

The time when the fictive motion takes place.  This may describe the time when the <fen>Road</fen> or a particular piece of the <fen>Road</fen> existed, or it may implicitly describe the time when an actual motion event occurred on the <fen>Road</fen>.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.

This is the person who believes some Phenomenon will take place in the future. It is normally expressed as an External Argument: <fex name='Cognizer'>Pat</fex> <t>expects</t> that the Yankees will win the World Series.

This is what the Cognizer believes will happen in the future. It can be expressed as a Finite Clause Complement, an NP Object, or a VP Complement with or without an NP Object (see General Grammatical Observations):
An entity that serves as the focus of a predicted <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Cognizer</fen> makes the prediction.
The location where the <fen>Cognizer</fen> foresees the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The role <fen>Experiencer</fen> indicates the person who experiences the emotion about their prior action.
The role <fen>Action</fen> marks expressions that indicate a prior action that the <fen>Experiencer</fen> has come to feel bad about.
The role <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a gesture or body part which is displaying the <fen>Emotional_state</fen> of the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The role <fen>Emotional_state</fen> is modified by an adjective  that indicates the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is contrite.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> or the <fen>Expressor</fen> is contrite.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> experiences the emotion or other internal state.

<fen>Content</fen> is what the <fen>Experiencer</fen>'s feelings or experiences are directed towards or based upon.  The <fen>Content</fen> differs from a stimulus because the <fen>Content</fen> is not construed as being direcly responsible for causing the emotion.

The Frame Element <fen>Expressor</fen> marks expressions that indicate a body part, gesture or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflect his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the area about which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> has the particular experience.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Event</fen> is the occasion or happening that <fen>Experiencer</fen>s in a certain emotional state participate in.
The time at which the <fen>Experiencer</fen> is in the specified emotional state.

The <fen>Comparison_event</fen> is the principal event being characteriszed by the <fen>Manner</fen>. The <fen>Manner</fen> of this <fen>Comparison_event</fen> is often used in comparison with the <fen>Foreground_event</fen>.
The <fen>Salient_entity</fen> that is associated with or directly responsible for the <fen>Comparison_activity</fen>.
The description of the <fen>Comparison_event</fen> or <fen>Comparison_activity</fen>.
A description of the <fen>Manner</fen>.
The <fen>Salient_entity</fen> conducts or engages in the <fen>Comparison_activity</fen> that is being described.
The <fen>Agent</fen> has committed a <fen>Wrong</fen> and is making <fen>Amends</fen>.
<fen>Wrong</fen> identifies the act committed by the <fen>Agent</fen> for which <fen>Amends</fen> are made.
<fen>Amends</fen> marks expressions that indicate what the <fen>Agent</fen> does to compensate for the <fen>Wrong</fen> that was committed.
The time at which the <fen>Agent</fen> atones for the <fen>Wrong</fen>.
The location at which the <fen>Agent</fen> expiates the <fen>Wrong</fen>.
listRoleExamples: The Way descends <fex>from the City of the Peak</fex> through a dense forest.
Valencia angles <fex>across the number streets</fex>.
<fex>Where</fex> does Interstate 80 enter the city ?
The paths crisscrossed <fex>the desert</fex>.
The cavern descended <fex>in a spiral</fex>.
The pass dips <fex>down</fex> about 2000 feet, and then <fex>back up</fex> again.
<fex>Thousands of years ago</fex>, the Roman roads criss-crossed this landscape.
<fex>In the mountains</fex>, Highway 60 winds and swerves a lot, so we lost a couple of hours from my estimate.
Pat expects <fex>that the Yankees will win the World Series</fex>.
Predictions <fex>about stock prices</fex> are notoriously undependable.
She predicted the outcry <fex>several months ago</fex>.
<fex>Even at the far side of the house</fex> I could predict what was going on the kitchen.
<fex>Smithers</fex> was contrite about his wrongdoings.
They confessed and repented <fex>their actions against the Soviet Union</fex>.
Repentant <fex>tears</fex> welled to his eyes.
Martha had a guilty <fex>conscience</fex> after selling inferior merchandise.
Everyone loves <fex>compliments</fex>.
The delight <fex>on her face</fex> was mixed with asonishment.
Mr. Whiskers was upset <fex>about his cat treats</fex>.
Tracy was in an irritated <fex>mood</fex>.
It felt pretty awkward to partake in such a nervous <fex>ceremony</fex>.
<fex>Last year</fex>, Bob was still interested in the young Republicans.
<fex>Syria</fex> has atoned for its support of Iraq.
Smithers is atoning <fex>for his misspent youth</fex>.
He atoned for his sin <fex>with good works</fex>.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: the hours of Two and three pm
the early part of the year
The Smith Museum and Art Gallery
the first decade of the 19th century
5 am on the morning of 5th April
Committee For Organising a Provisional Government'
